Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Single Molecule Analysis of a Major Cytoskeletal Regulator in Migrating Cells

POR.DRECONTENT:
Directed cell movement in response to chemical signals occurs during development, axon guidance, wound healing, tumor progression, and the immune response.  Cells interpret external cues through signaling networks and then engage migration machinery to generate mechanical force for membrane protrusion at its leading edge.  Our work focuses specifically on the interface between the cell’s signaling guidance system and the molecules that generate motive forces.  My summer project focused on analyzing the behavior of these molecules in living cells using high-resolution microscopy techniques. Understanding biophysical behaviors of individual signaling molecules allows one to explore how emergent protein properties underscore directed cell migration and ultimately enhances of our understanding of cell migration disorders like cancer metastasis or chronic inflammation.

The laboratory of Naoki Watanabe in Sendai, Japan was particularly well-suited for this project because Dr. Watanabe has pioneered the technique of fluorescent single-molecule imaging. He demonstrated how the building blocks of the cell's migration apparatus, a protein called actin, flows from the cell periphery to its interior as it is assembled into polymeric networks. During my visit, I showed how two related actin-polymerizing factors also underwent this retrograde recycling movement and discovered a novel mechanism by which these proteins find their appropriate binding sites. Unfortunately, Sendai is now internationally recognized for the tragic earthquake and tsunami that occurred a few months after I departed. However, I recently returned to Tohoku University where I conducted my summer project to discuss final revisions for a manuscript we submitted as a result of experiments performed during my EAPSI fellowship. Despite the enormous challenge of rebuilding and replacing equipment, I am happy to report that the Watanabe lab has resumed all research activities.

I am deeply grateful for the NSF EAPSI program because it enabled me to finish my graduate studies with a fruitful collaboration that lead to an exciting new piece of biology. Furthermore, I took advantage of the EAPSI travel budget to communicate my work with other researchers in Japan and also to interview for post-doctoral research programs. Indeed, I will be using my biochemistry and new-found microscopy skills starting in the fall to study biological rhythms with Hiroki Ueda's group at the RIKEN in Kobe, Japan.
